On Monday 09 June 2008 22:57, C=C3=A9dric Beust =E2=99=94 wrote:
> It's the=
 definition of a log:  most of the time, you don't need it,
> but it's hand=
y if you need to double check something after your tests
> have run.

That'=
s true for logs like server logs that collect data from "the 
outside". It =
doesn't make any sense to me for test logs, where no 
"outside" influences =
the result. Unless of course you don't trust your 
test framework.

> Not j=
ust for BDD, not sure why you want to single this out.

For its documention=
 and communication purposes. I understand that a list 
of tests (or a list =
of "the program should") is helpful to show to the 
customer. But such a li=
st at the unit test level is probably overkill.

> I know of organizations =
that commit all the test results (HTML and
> others) to databases every day=
 so they can run long-term statistics
> and various other metrics over the =
course of time.

Yes. I also know people who think waterfall is a good idea=
.

Robert
